message:
- Can we consider the software engineering career as a mathematically-dependent major? 

- If you're to recommend one must-have mathematical course, what would it be? Any recommended sources? (of course for SE or CS related concepts)

data.message: Discrete Mathematics tops them all I suppose.
I'm having the same question as yours. Currently I'm studying calculus,  I wonder if it's valuable to a software engineer?

Technically computer science started as a branch of discreet math. 
Reality wise, in these days, you rarely need to have the knowledge of some advanced mathematical theories.
People in the field of CS need to have a very strong mathematical background in less than 3%-5% of CS fields, for example:

1- people who design knew algorithms, and by design here, I mean formal designing of new algorithms that require mathematical proofs like designing a new compression algorithm
2- in very certain areas in game development. Like those who build the graphical pipeline and physics engine (in these days, people mostly use middleware for that)
3- data scientists.

In short, if your target is to be a very strong software engineer, then there are much important fields that you should focus your time on
don't hate on me bas math is absolute bullshit.

Not sure if this adds to the discussion, but sharing my little experience. Phenomenally strongest "smartest" engineers I have been fortunate to work with were surprisingly Math. graduates - either Ph.D. or Master holders. Not a rule for sure, but my guess Math. develops the brain efficiency in some ways :) May be I am wrong, just my thought!

Im studying a CS major curriculum and it got discreet math, calcus and probability.
They are there for a reason.
